Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Benzoate and pH Stress in Experimental Evolution of Escherichia coli

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In all environments, bacteria experience change in pH. Low pH amplifies the bacterial uptake of organic acids found in food, such as the aspirin-related compounds benzoate and salicylate. Study of benzoate stress and adaptation yields insights about microbial interactions with salicylate-rich food plants such as fruits and berries. Plant salicylates are important defense molecules which stress the bacteria of plant-associated microbial communities. For this project, undergraduate researchers will investigate how the bacterium Escherichia coli K-12 responds to acid-enhanced uptake of benzoate or salicylate.

Preliminary results show that over generations of benzoate exposure, bacteria undergo surprising adaptations including the loss of drug resistance, more durable cell shape, and altered production of a variety of organic compounds. Benzoate-adapted clones show selection for mutations that enhance tolerance of organic acids at the cost of sensitivity to antimicrobials such as chloramphenicol. Undergraduate researchers will perform genetic analysis to test whether the fitness gains and chloramphenicol sensitivity are associated with loss of organic acid-induced gene networks, or whether the fitness changes derive from previously unknown mechanisms. A possible mechanism of fitness increase is the loss of energy-expensive gene expression, to overcome the low-energy stress caused by the benzoate depletion of protonmotive force. The role of low-energy stress will be tested by treatment with uncoupler molecules such as CCCP that deplete proton motive force; and by testing bacterial responses to high pH, a different condition that incurs low-energy stress. Another mechanism of benzoate-adapted clones may involve improvement of pH homeostasis. Undergraduates will measure bacterial cytoplasmic pH using ratiometric fluorescence microscopy, by a method used in the PI's lab and provided on request to other labs. Benzoate-adapted clones also show changes in cell morphology. Undergraduate researchers will test the role of mutant alleles in maintaining cell shape in acid or in base. Unusual cell shape phenotypes can yield clues as to mechanisms of cell division, a process important for human control of microbial communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award focused on organic acids and pH stress in Escherichia coli. Acid stress amplifies the reversal of antibiotic resistance that occurs during evolution in the presence of aspirin-derivatived acids. These aspirin derivatives, such as benzoic acid and salicylic acid, are aromatic acids that have the property of conducting protons (hydrogen ions) into the cell. By conducting hydrogen ions these acids deplete the cell's energy reserves stored in the transmembrane proton potential. Bacteria adapt to the presence of benzoate or other aspirin derivatives by selection of mutations that knock out multidrug efflux pumps. Selected mutants also include strains that express larger-hole porins, protein complexes in the outer membrane that admit nutrients and antibiotics into the cell. These surprising findings suggest ways to devise procedures that reverse drug resistance in human intestinal microbiomes and in aquatic environments.

Bacteria also undergo adaptation to growth in alkali (high pH), a condition relevant to infection of the alkaline pancreatic duct. High pH selects for mutations in the RpoS global stress regulator. A finding of general interest was that evolution under pH stress conditions select for mutations in the very genes most highly expressed under those conditions. This fitness tradeoff may occur because genes expressed under a new stress condition have secondary effects that decrease fitness under long-term stress exposure.

Acid stress was also investigated by experimental evolution of the archaeon, Halobacterium NRC-1. Growth of this salt-loving archaeon requires extreme concentrations of NaCl. This work is one of the first reports of experimental evolution with genomic analysis of an archaeon. The analysis of evolved genomes reveals extensive genome instability, including large-scale deletions and duplications. Acid-adapted strains of Halobacterium show mutations affecting an arginine-ornithine antiporter, a component of catabolism that consumes hydrogen ions. This arginine catabolism resembles that of the acid stress response found in oral streptococcus bacteria. It is remarkable that the extreme salt-adapted archaeon has evolved an acid protection mechanism similar to that of human-associated bacteria involved in acidic tooth decay.

The broader impacts of this project include training of 25 undergraduate researchers through the First-years First program, as well as 4 high school students. A total of 19 undergraduates and 2 high school students coauthored publications. A total of ten undergraduates pursued graduate or postbac research, including seven PhD programs.
